data.author: 404x
data.content: Interesting to see Ryan Matthiesen take a stake here recently. He is investment manager at Haywood, big players in Canadian mining equity deals https://www.haywood.com/ So a pretty big name to have bought into a micro cap like this. Where it gets more interesting is if you look at some of the deals Haywood have overseen. Canadian Nickel Company was one, that's seen blockbuster returns as Canadian government took a big stake in it. And most recently Galantas Gold. Galantas links to Conroy probably go without saying, both geologically and as the only other listed name in Irish gold. Galantas has seen spectacular gains this year with a deal brokered by none other than Haywood.

data.author: 404x

data.author: 404x
data.content: As well as Haywood, I suspect these guys have potential to be kingmakers here. They are investing in Irish gold in a big way - worth looking how many millions they spent to acquire majority stake in Galantas' Irish property - while Galantas plc are pivoting towards Chile. https://galantas.com/news/galantas-gold-closes-transaction-to-form-joint-venture-with-ocean-partners-uk-limited-to-develop-omagh-gold-project-in-northern/ The fact these guys are pouring big cash into renovating that mine north of the border is telling.  Then you look at the links here. Conroy own land in area surrounding that mine. Conroy's gold is on same geological fault line. And south of the border, as we know Conrory have a significant amount gold in the ground - hundreds of thousands of ounces - more gold than the Ocean Partners property. Once that gold is dug up, the Ocean Partners property could provide the processing facilities. The more you look, the more links and synergies you find. I'd say some form of M&A is nailed on here.

data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.author: Goldbug99
data.content: @Robemy71 : You are being disingenuous here. It's a genuine concern. Just because the company owns (some of) the land doesn't stop 3rd party objections/appeals. Anyone, including the usual green suspects and their barristers in far-away leafy Dublin suburbs, can throw spanners in the works. Ireland has history here! It's not all down to the locals hoping to score big on land sales and jobs. The hope here has to be that grades sufficient to justify underground costs and too deep for an open pit are found in this next drilling round, because a massive low-grade open pit is problematic. The issues with low-grades are the enormous volume of tailings, and open pits, the large volume of waste rock generated. Both require unsightly, land-hungry surface disposal, and will be rich in pyrite, arsenic and other nasties, prone to AMD. Nearby massive gypsum pits and limestone quarries cited as precedents don't have these issues! Bear in mind, Dalradian's plan is all undergound at 13-15g/t and still ran into problems. Better to face the issues and work around them than stick your fingers in your ears and whistle, as you seem to be doing. Pretending a problem doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Some clarity/assurance they are pre-empting this from the company would help here!

data.author: Ortus
data.content: I think the Antimony (Sb) at Clontibret is going to drive interest here with grades up to 14%. For context, most Sb mines operate at 1–3% Sb and 10%+ is exceptional. This is why they're drilling where they are. Sb is very much in focus right now and I'm seeing investors looking for Sb exposure. There are very few projects showing real grades so eyes will be on CGNR if the assays look good. If continuity at depth is confirmed Sb becomes a serious value driver here, maybe as much as the gold. Sb not currently reflected in the valuation. Market hasn’t caught up yet. Maybe the Canadian TR1 guy has though.

data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.author: 404x
data.content: As well as Haywood, I suspect these guys have potential to be kingmakers here. They are investing in Irish gold in a big way - worth looking how many millions they spent to acquire majority stake in Galantas' Irish property - while Galantas plc are pivoting towards Chile. https://galantas.com/news/galantas-gold-closes-transaction-to-form-joint-venture-with-ocean-partners-uk-limited-to-develop-omagh-gold-project-in-northern/ The fact these guys are pouring big cash into renovating that mine north of the border is telling.  Then you look at the links here. Conroy own land in area surrounding that mine. Conroy's gold is on same geological fault line. And south of the border, as we know Conrory have a significant amount gold in the ground - hundreds of thousands of ounces - more gold than the Ocean Partners property. Once that gold is dug up, the Ocean Partners property could provide the processing facilities. The more you look, the more links and synergies you find. I'd say some form of M&A is nailed on here.

data.author: 404x
data.content: Agree with you Robemy71. There is support for the project at a local level. There's the obvious like jobs and taxes it would bring, and there is such a long lineage of Irish gold from being baked into mythology of the past south of the border. There will always be nimbys wherever you go, but the gold story sells itself. Issues around planning are a bit of a red herring at this stage anyway. This is an explorer and will be valued as such. You see explorers in all over the world without a permit, let alone functioning mine, and with fewer proven ounces in the ground like this has - valued in excess of Conroy. Plenty of names just at the stage of drilling holes valued in the tens of millions in nightmare jurisdictions like Mali.

data.author: Goldbug99
data.content: @Robemy71 : You are being disingenuous here. It's a genuine concern. Just because the company owns (some of) the land doesn't stop 3rd party objections/appeals. Anyone, including the usual green suspects and their barristers in far-away leafy Dublin suburbs, can throw spanners in the works. Ireland has history here! It's not all down to the locals hoping to score big on land sales and jobs. The hope here has to be that grades sufficient to justify underground costs and too deep for an open pit are found in this next drilling round, because a massive low-grade open pit is problematic. The issues with low-grades are the enormous volume of tailings, and open pits, the large volume of waste rock generated. Both require unsightly, land-hungry surface disposal, and will be rich in pyrite, arsenic and other nasties, prone to AMD. Nearby massive gypsum pits and limestone quarries cited as precedents don't have these issues! Bear in mind, Dalradian's plan is all undergound at 13-15g/t and still ran into problems. Better to face the issues and work around them than stick your fingers in your ears and whistle, as you seem to be doing. Pretending a problem doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Some clarity/assurance they are pre-empting this from the company would help here!

data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.title: Half-yearly results for the six months ended 30 November 2025
data.full_content:
2 Feb 2026 07:34
Conroy Gold & Natural Resources Plc - Half-yearly results for the six months ended 30 November 2025
Conroy Gold & Natural Resources Plc - Half-yearly results for the six months ended 30 November 2025
PR Newswire
LONDON, United Kingdom, February 02
2 February 2026
Conroy Gold and Natural Resources plc
(“Conroy” or the “Company”)
Half-yearly results for the six months ended 30 November 2025
Conroy (AIM: CGNR), the Irish-based resource company focused on advancing its “Discs of Gold” project in Ireland, is pleased to announce its results for the six months ended 30 November 2025. Details of these can be found below and a full copy of the interim results statement can be viewed on the Company’s website.
Highlights:
Restructuring completed in relation to amounts owing to Directors and former Directors in excess of €3.3 million including a write off of €680,000 with the balance being deferred and ultimately repayable from success-based instruments tied to commercial production and a material increase in the share price.
Oversubscribed private placement at 10.0p raising approximately €2.0 million (£1.7 million) with a further inflow of €0.5 million (£0.4 million) from the exercise of warrants during the period.
The first phase of a new drilling programme at Clontibret covering ca 2,000 metres commenced in November with the planned holes aiming to follow on the gold and antimony plunge trends at Clontibret identified during the detailed relogging project.
Net assets of the group were €22,407,969 as at 30 November 2025 and the group made a profit for the six-month period of €278,636 after the effects of the debt write off.
John Sherman, Chairman, commented:
“The balance sheet repair delivered during the reporting period, including fundraisings involving both new and existing shareholders, is allowing the Company to purposefully advance its “Discs of Gold” project.
The first phase of a new drilling programme at the Clontibret gold deposit commenced at the end of the reporting period; the work aims to assess the potential for higher-grade structurally controlled gold mineralization at depth to expand the deposit, as well as testing the antimony-bearing lode system for its potential contribution to project economics.
I look forward to seeing the initial results of this work by the end of the current calendar quarter."
About the “Discs of Gold” Project
Conroy Gold’s “Discs of Gold” project in Ireland is defined by two parallel district scale gold trends, extending over c.90km, which are 100% held under license by the Company, and anchored by the Clontibret gold deposit.
The Clontibret target area contains a currently defined 517Koz gold resource @ 2.0 g/t Au (320Koz Au Indicated and 197Koz Au Inferred (2017)) which remains open in multiple directions.
The Company has identified a further seven gold targets in its license area with the Clay Lake and Creenkill gold targets being of particular interest.
Gold occurs in multiple styles in the Company’s license area, including free gold, refractory gold in arsenopyrite and gold associated with pyrite and antimony (stibnite), suggesting multiple hydrothermal events seeded the deposit. There are clear geological analogies between the “Discs” targets and large gold deposits in Southeastern Australia and Atlantic Canada.
For further information please contact

www.conroygold.com
Chairman’s statement
Dear Shareholder,
I present your Company’s Half-Yearly Report and Condensed Financial Statements for the six-month period ended 30 November 2025.
The critical action for the Company in the period was the repair to its balance sheet through two steps as follows:
1) in late August 2025 when the share price was 5.3p, the Company entered into an agreement with certain current and former directors (“the Participants”) to restructure amounts owed to them (in excess of €3.3M) into success-based instruments tied to commercial production and a material increase in the share price; and 2) in October 2025, the Company closed an
oversubscribed private placement at 10p raising €2.0M (c. £1.7M), with a further inflow of €0.5M (c. £0.4M) coming from the exercise of 12-month warrants at 9.5p issued as part of the Company’s October 2024 fundraising.
Further details on these two steps are in my letter sent to shareholders dated 26 November 2025 along with the Company’s Annual Report for 2025.
To close my comments on this action, I was pleased to see shareholders vote at the AGM in December to approve the August agreement with near unanimity, allowing the Company to have a clear focus on the futur

data.content: From a couple of months ago but just came across this now. He's a gold mining veteran and an early investor in a number of significant names across sector over many years, seems significant he has a position here. ____ "I’m going to do something I have never done before in 24 years of writing about resource stocks. I am going to write about a gold stock located in Ireland but only listed on the AIM exchange in the UK. The stock is Conroy Gold and Natural Resources Plc (CGNR-AIM). They look forward to obtaining an OTCQB listing down the road. Conroy already has a JORC (similar to the 43-101) resource of 517,000 ounces of gold. They have 100% prospecting rights over two district size gold trends in Ireland. They have a 65km strike at the Orlock Bridge trend and an additional 24km length of the Skullmartin trend. Their prospecting rights cover over a 1,000 square km area. Few people know this but Ireland produces more zinc per square km than any country in the world. It is a quiet but major mining country. A target measuring 3km by 2km with high tonnage potential was discovered near Clear Lake within the Orlock Bridge gold trend. Drilling in this area by Conroy shows gold mineralization over 100 meters, the longest continuous intercepts in the British Isles."

data.author: Goldbug99
data.content: @Robemy71 : You are being disingenuous here. It's a genuine concern. Just because the company owns (some of) the land doesn't stop 3rd party objections/appeals. Anyone, including the usual green suspects and their barristers in far-away leafy Dublin suburbs, can throw spanners in the works. Ireland has history here! It's not all down to the locals hoping to score big on land sales and jobs. The hope here has to be that grades sufficient to justify underground costs and too deep for an open pit are found in this next drilling round, because a massive low-grade open pit is problematic. The issues with low-grades are the enormous volume of tailings, and open pits, the large volume of waste rock generated. Both require unsightly, land-hungry surface disposal, and will be rich in pyrite, arsenic and other nasties, prone to AMD. Nearby massive gypsum pits and limestone quarries cited as precedents don't have these issues! Bear in mind, Dalradian's plan is all undergound at 13-15g/t and still ran into problems. Better to face the issues and work around them than stick your fingers in your ears and whistle, as you seem to be doing. Pretending a problem doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Some clarity/assurance they are pre-empting this from the company would help here!

data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.author: tbcx
data.content: Re pre-feasibility you could apply same critique to any explorers. Drilling always comes before pre-feasibility but they've only scratched the surface here. The project has effectively been dormant for more than a decade because they haven't had the financials to expand the program. What has changed is that with these new investors on board they do. The balance sheet has been fixed, debts cleared, they banked £2.1m cash. That will go a significant distance to expanding the resource. Starting with current drill program. Gamechanger now is they are able to drill at depth. Based on everything we know about the high grades closer to surface, and geological similarities with other significant finds globally, there is massive potential here nowhere near reflected in today's market cap. Suspect this is why they have so much support from the Canadian heavy hitters. As company themselves say, Clontibret has "potential for multi-million-ounce gold mineralisation at depth". Multi million.

data.author: tbcx
data.content: From the website: "free gold, refractory gold in arsenopyrite and gold associated with pyrite and antimony (stibnite), suggesting multiple hydrothermal events seeded the deposit". You are only picking out refractory when the reality is the geology here is varied and corresponds with other large scale deposits.

data.author: DeathStranding

data.author: DeathStranding

data.author: tbcx
data.content: Implying it's all refractory is misleading. The deposit includes free gold and pyrite/antimony gold. We have no idea about the ratio of each. Suspect the heavy hitters that have funded this must be confident about the viability of the resource. Valuation wise, you'll struggle to find another company in the developed world with a JORC resource over 0.5m oz AU  PLUS £2.1m cash banked to advance current program at a market cap this low. In fact if you know of any let me know as I'll buy immediately.

data.author: DeathStranding

data.author: tbcx
data.content: What has changed and I'd suggest reason it's captured investors attention is not just the gold price - which can't be overstated enough, it totally transforms the economics of a project like this -  but the level of undervaluation here compared to peers. It is very rare to see an explorer anywhere in the world with this kind of resource at a market cap this low. The other dynamic that will significantly move the needle here is well known names in North American mining getting on board including Haywood's investment manager buying a stake. Then there's Eric Sprott putting money into Galantas which owns a dormant mine north of the border that now looks set to be coming back into production. Irish gold is having a genuine moment.

data.content: Continued "Conroy made the Clontibret gold discovery after resampling samples from the historic antimony mines located there. data.author: 404x
data.content: From a couple of months ago but just came across this now. He's a gold mining veteran and an early investor in a number of significant names across sector over many years, seems significant he has a position here. ____ "I’m going to do something I have never done before in 24 years of writing about resource stocks. I am going to write about a gold stock located in Ireland but only listed on the AIM exchange in the UK. The stock is Conroy Gold and Natural Resources Plc (CGNR-AIM). They look forward to obtaining an OTCQB listing down the road. Conroy already has a JORC (similar to the 43-101) resource of 517,000 ounces of gold. They have 100% prospecting rights over two district size gold trends in Ireland. They have a 65km strike at the Orlock Bridge trend and an additional 24km length of the Skullmartin trend. Their prospecting rights cover over a 1,000 square km area. Few people know this but Ireland produces more zinc per square km than any country in the world. It is a quiet but major mining country. A target measuring 3km by 2km with high tonnage potential was discovered near Clear Lake within the Orlock Bridge gold trend. Drilling in this area by Conroy shows gold mineralization over 100 meters, the longest continuous intercepts in the British Isles."

data.author: 404x
data.content: Agree with you Robemy71. There is support for the project at a local level. There's the obvious like jobs and taxes it would bring, and there is such a long lineage of Irish gold from being baked into mythology of the past south of the border. There will always be nimbys wherever you go, but the gold story sells itself. Issues around planning are a bit of a red herring at this stage anyway. This is an explorer and will be valued as such. You see explorers in all over the world without a permit, let alone functioning mine, and with fewer proven ounces in the ground like this has - valued in excess of Conroy. Plenty of names just at the stage of drilling holes valued in the tens of millions in nightmare jurisdictions like Mali.

data.author: Goldbug99
data.content: @Robemy71 : You are being disingenuous here. It's a genuine concern. Just because the company owns (some of) the land doesn't stop 3rd party objections/appeals. Anyone, including the usual green suspects and their barristers in far-away leafy Dublin suburbs, can throw spanners in the works. Ireland has history here! It's not all down to the locals hoping to score big on land sales and jobs. The hope here has to be that grades sufficient to justify underground costs and too deep for an open pit are found in this next drilling round, because a massive low-grade open pit is problematic. The issues with low-grades are the enormous volume of tailings, and open pits, the large volume of waste rock generated. Both require unsightly, land-hungry surface disposal, and will be rich in pyrite, arsenic and other nasties, prone to AMD. Nearby massive gypsum pits and limestone quarries cited as precedents don't have these issues! Bear in mind, Dalradian's plan is all undergound at 13-15g/t and still ran into problems. Better to face the issues and work around them than stick your fingers in your ears and whistle, as you seem to be doing. Pretending a problem doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Some clarity/assurance they are pre-empting this from the company would help here!

data.author: DeathStranding
data.content: The stated objective of the Demir JV was to take Clontibret to development ready status. That means an open pit. They did stepout drilling which was negative (and pre JV CGNR did infill drilling which had no impact on  the resource - no increase in ounces, no classification upgrade). They drilled multiple other prospects with no material results, and Clay Lake which was too low grade. Therefore no progress with development, they walked. Far from proving nothing, they proved it is not a development project. The current strategy is a different one - to explore a high grade underground concept. Will it yield meaninful information? Hope you are right.

I think the other 2 might be less than that. As for double digit grams over double digit metres that would obviously be good. Even grades of half that would be something though if the widths are good. It would prove that Clontibret is much bigger than 500k oz.

data.author: Ortus
data.content: I think the Antimony (Sb) at Clontibret is going to drive interest here with grades up to 14%. For context, most Sb mines operate at 1–3% Sb and 10%+ is exceptional. This is why they're drilling where they are. Sb is very much in focus right now and I'm seeing investors looking for Sb exposure. There are very few projects showing real grades so eyes will be on CGNR if the assays look good. If continuity at depth is confirmed Sb becomes a serious value driver here, maybe as much as the gold. Sb not currently reflected in the valuation. Market hasn’t caught up yet. Maybe the Canadian TR1 guy has though.

data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.author: 404x
data.content: As well as Haywood, I suspect these guys have potential to be kingmakers here. They are investing in Irish gold in a big way - worth looking how many millions they spent to acquire majority stake in Galantas' Irish property - while Galantas plc are pivoting towards Chile. https://galantas.com/news/galantas-gold-closes-transaction-to-form-joint-venture-with-ocean-partners-uk-limited-to-develop-omagh-gold-project-in-northern/ The fact these guys are pouring big cash into renovating that mine north of the border is telling.  Then you look at the links here. Conroy own land in area surrounding that mine. Conroy's gold is on same geological fault line. And south of the border, as we know Conrory have a significant amount gold in the ground - hundreds of thousands of ounces - more gold than the Ocean Partners property. Once that gold is dug up, the Ocean Partners property could provide the processing facilities. The more you look, the more links and synergies you find. I'd say some form of M&A is nailed on here.

data.author: Jontfsi
data.content: The company has acquired and developed a proprietary oxidation technology that transforms sulfide ore into oxide ore, making previously unrecoverable gold accessible through conventional heap leaching. This technology reduces capital expenditure for Metates from $3.5 billion to $360 million, increases IRR from under 10% to 35%, and enables a smaller initial operation of 15,000 tons per day with potential to expand. The technology has been proven on a commercial scale at the Hycroft mine, achieving 80-90% gold recovery from previously 20% recoverable material, and has potential applications for many other refractory deposits globally.

Based on everything we know about the high grades closer to surface, and geological similarities with other significant finds globally, there is massive potential here nowhere near reflected in today's market cap. Suspect this is why they have so much support from the Canadian heavy hitters. As company themselves say, Clontibret has "potential for multi-million-ounce gold mineralisation at depth". Multi million.

data.author: 404x
data.content: From a couple of months ago but just came across this now. He's a gold mining veteran and an early investor in a number of significant names across sector over many years, seems significant he has a position here. ____ "I’m going to do something I have never done before in 24 years of writing about resource stocks. I am going to write about a gold stock located in Ireland but only listed on the AIM exchange in the UK. The stock is Conroy Gold and Natural Resources Plc (CGNR-AIM). They look forward to obtaining an OTCQB listing down the road. Conroy already has a JORC (similar to the 43-101) resource of 517,000 ounces of gold. They have 100% prospecting rights over two district size gold trends in Ireland. They have a 65km strike at the Orlock Bridge trend and an additional 24km length of the Skullmartin trend. Their prospecting rights cover over a 1,000 square km area. Few people know this but Ireland produces more zinc per square km than any country in the world. It is a quiet but major mining country. A target measuring 3km by 2km with high tonnage potential was discovered near Clear Lake within the Orlock Bridge gold trend. Drilling in this area by Conroy shows gold mineralization over 100 meters, the longest continuous intercepts in the British Isles."

data.author: Goldbug99
data.content: @Robemy71 : You are being disingenuous here. It's a genuine concern. Just because the company owns (some of) the land doesn't stop 3rd party objections/appeals. Anyone, including the usual green suspects and their barristers in far-away leafy Dublin suburbs, can throw spanners in the works. Ireland has history here! It's not all down to the locals hoping to score big on land sales and jobs. The hope here has to be that grades sufficient to justify underground costs and too deep for an open pit are found in this next drilling round, because a massive low-grade open pit is problematic. The issues with low-grades are the enormous volume of tailings, and open pits, the large volume of waste rock generated. Both require unsightly, land-hungry surface disposal, and will be rich in pyrite, arsenic and other nasties, prone to AMD. Nearby massive gypsum pits and limestone quarries cited as precedents don't have these issues! Bear in mind, Dalradian's plan is all undergound at 13-15g/t and still ran into problems. Better to face the issues and work around them than stick your fingers in your ears and whistle, as you seem to be doing. Pretending a problem doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Some clarity/assurance they are pre-empting this from the company would help here!

There are very few projects showing real grades so eyes will be on CGNR if the assays look good. If continuity at depth is confirmed Sb becomes a serious value driver here, maybe as much as the gold. data.author: NanoCapInvestor
data.content: Anyone spotted today's gold price? Anyone? US$4,920 per ounce! Now, consider the brutal, beautiful irony of Conroy Gold (CGNR). While the world watches that number flash, this company holds a JORC-backed 517,000 ounces of that exact asset. And when you run the math, a staggering US$2.54 billion of in-situ gold is spat out. Now, here’s the punchline that should stop you cold: the market is valuing the entire company at £11.5 million (16p per share)! Let’s sit with that disconnect for a second. The market is essentially pricing their gold at US$28 an ounce. That’s not a discount; it’s a cognitive breakdown. This is the precise, fleeting anomaly that defines the early innings of a resource bull market — where reality hasn't yet caught up to the price on the screen. So, what’s a sane valuation? Applying a skeletal, risk-heavy metric of just US$50 per resource ounce — a 99% discount to spot —values their current resource at over US$25 million. That’s the conservative floor, and we’ve already blown past the current cap. Factor in the multi-million-ounce targets, the drills turning right now, and the £2 million+ fuel in the tank, and a re-rate to £50-80 million isn’t speculation; it’s simply arithmetic catching up. BOTTOM LINE: In a world of US$4,920 gold, owning a slice of a proven US$2.5 billion deposit for a microscopic £11.5 million valuation isn't an investment — it's a logical inevitability waiting to happen. The market will close this gap; it's only a matter of when. ATB .

data.author: 404x
data.content: As well as Haywood, I suspect these guys have potential to be kingmakers here. They are investing in Irish gold in a big way - worth looking how many millions they spent to acquire majority stake in Galantas' Irish property - while Galantas plc are pivoting towards Chile. https://galantas.com/news/galantas-gold-closes-transaction-to-form-joint-venture-with-ocean-partners-uk-limited-to-develop-omagh-gold-project-in-northern/ The fact these guys are pouring big cash into renovating that mine north of the border is telling.  Then you look at the links here. Conroy own land in area surrounding that mine. Conroy's gold is on same geological fault line. And south of the border, as we know Conrory have a significant amount gold in the ground - hundreds of thousands of ounces - more gold than the Ocean Partners property. Once that gold is dug up, the Ocean Partners property could provide the processing facilities. The more you look, the more links and synergies you find. I'd say some form of M&A is nailed on here.

company_30s.what_they_do: CGNR is an exploration and development company that looks for gold and other metals in the Irish and British Isles. It drills, samples and studies deposits to turn them into mineable projects.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Exploration firms can bring huge upside if they find a viable resource, and the market is eager for any sign of a new gold play in a low‑interest‑rate environment.
company_30s.current_state: Still in the exploration phase, no production yet, but it has just started a new drilling programme and is raising capital. The shares are trading near historic lows, reflecting the lack of proven assets.

rns_narrative: The company has been busy with drilling and sample work – new anomalies at Skullmartin and antimony samples at Clontibret suggest the geology is interesting.
Corporate actions such as a private placement, AGM updates and a new broker appointment show management is keeping the capital base stable while preparing for future funding.
Financial results for the last half‑year and full year are being released, giving investors a view of cash burn and the ability to fund the next drilling phase.

crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bulls left – classic contrarian silence.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears point to a lack of production, high costs and the risk that the drilling could turn up nothing.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: From panic to apathy – the market has moved on, leaving room for a surprise turnaround.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends is dead. If a positive story lands, the surprise factor will be huge.

Any announcement of a resource estimate or mine plan would give the stock a clear upside.
A technical breakout above the last low or a spike in volume could confirm the start of a reversal.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for a daily close above the recent low with a volume spike, short covering signs, and any positive drilling news.
expect_next.timing_regime: We are in late‑stage wash‑out – the market has already sold most of the weak hands, leaving a tight spring ready to snap.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Contrarian Bullish – the deep crash and dead sentiment make this a classic contrarian play.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: The stock is down over 80% from its peak. A 40% bounce, which is the average for deep crash signals, would double the price. The compressed chart suggests a strong spring that will snap once a catalyst appears.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: If the drilling fails to produce a viable resource, the price could drop another 10–20%. The downside is limited because the market has already taken most of the weak hands.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter with 25% of the target position now, using a tight stop just below the recent low. Add 25% more if volume confirms the breakout or if new drilling results are released.
playbook.if_watching: Hold until you see a daily close above the low with volume above the 5‑day average, or until a positive resource announcement is made.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this if you see any red flags such as a delisting warning or a bankruptcy filing – otherwise the setup is worth a contrarian bet.

ai_insights.bottom_line: Deep crash, dead sentiment, active drilling – a classic contrarian play with a 1:5 risk‑reward if the next drilling round turns up a viable resource.
